text: Recombinant <extra_id_0> NFAT1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> NFATp <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) is regulated by calcineurin in T cells and mediates transcription of several cytokine genes .
Transcription factors of the NFAT family play a key role in the transcription of cytokine genes and other genes during the immune response .

We have identified two new isoforms of the transcription factor <extra_id_0> NFAT1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( previously termed <extra_id_0> NFATp <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) that are the predominant isoforms expressed in murine and human T cells .

When expressed in Jurkat T cells , recombinant <extra_id_0> NFAT1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is regulated , as expected , by the <extra_id_0> calmodulin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - dependent phosphatase calcineurin , and its function is inhibited by the immunosuppressive agent cyclosporin A ( CsA ) .

Transactivation by recombinant <extra_id_0> NFAT1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in Jurkat T cells requires dual stimulation with ionomycin and phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate ; this activity is potentiated by coexpression of constitutively active calcineurin and is inhibited by CsA .

Immunocytochemical analysis indicates that recombinant <extra_id_0> NFAT1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> localizes in the cytoplasm of transiently transfected T cells and translocates into the nucleus in a CsA - sensitive manner following ionomycin stimulation .

When expressed in COS cells , however , <extra_id_0> NFAT1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is capable of transactivation , but it is not regulated correctly : its subcellular localization and transcriptional function are not affected by stimulation of the COS cells with ionomycin and phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate .

Recombinant <extra_id_0> NFAT1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> can mediate transcription of the <extra_id_0> interleukin-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> interleukin-4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> tumor necrosis factor alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and <extra_id_0> granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoters in T cells , suggesting that <extra_id_0> NFAT1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> contributes to the CsA - sensitive transcription of these genes during the immune response .
